column2: The Master exclaimed, "What a work for philanthropy!
column3: The Master exclaimed, "What a work for philanthropy!

column2: He would require indeed to be a sage!
column3: He would require indeed to be a sage!

column2: He would put into shade even Yau and Shun!--Well, a philanthropic person, desiring for himself a firm footing, is led on to give one to others; desiring for himself an enlightened perception of things, he is led on to help others to be similarly enlightened.
column3: He would put into shade even Yau and Shun!--Well, a philanthropic person, desiring for himself a firm footing, is led on to give one to others; desiring for himself an enlightened perception of things, he is led on to help others to be similarly enlightened.

column2: If one could take an illustration coming closer home to us than yours, that might be made the starting-point for speaking about philanthropy."
column3: If one could take an illustration coming closer home to us than yours, that might be made the starting point for speaking about philanthropy."

column2: [Footnote 14: At this time Confucius was Criminal Judge in his native State of Lu.
column3: [Footnote fourteen: At this time Confucius was Criminal Judge in his native State of Lu.

column2: Yuen Sz had been a disciple.
column3: Yuen s z had been a disciple.

column2: The commentators add that this was the officer's proper salary, and that he did wrong to refuse it.]
column3: The commentators add that this was the officer's proper salary, and that he did wrong to refuse it.]

column2: [Footnote 15: The doctrine afterwards known by that name, and which gave its title to a Confucian treatise.]

column2: BOOK VII
column3: BOOK seven

column2: Characteristics of Confucius--An Incident
column3: Characteristics of Confucius-An Incident

column2: Said the Master:--
column3: Said the Master:--

column2: I, as a transmitter[16] and not an originator, and as one who believes in and loves the ancients, venture to compare myself with our old P'ang.	I, as a transmitter[sixteen] and not an originator, and as one who believes in and loves the ancients, venture to compare myself with our old P'ang.
column3: false

column2: What find you indeed in me?--a quiet brooder and memorizer; a student never satiated with learning; an unwearied monitor of others!	What find you indeed in me?--a quiet brooder and memorizer; a student never satiated with learning; an unwearied monitor of others!
column3: false

column2: The things which weigh heavily upon my mind are these--failure to improve in the virtues, failure in discussion of what is learnt, inability to walk according to knowledge received as to what is right and just, inability also to reform what has been amiss.
column3: The things which weigh heavily upon my mind are these-failure to improve in the virtues, failure in discussion of what is learnt, inability to walk according to knowledge received as to what is right and just, inability also to reform what has been amiss.

column2: In his hours of recreation and refreshment the Master's manner was easy and unconstrained, affable and winning.
column3: In his hours of recreation and refreshment the Master's manner was easy and unconstrained, affable and winning.

column2: Once he exclaimed, "Alas!
column3: Once he exclaimed, "Alas!

column2: I must be getting very feeble; 'tis long since I have had a repetition of the dreams in which I used to see the Duke of Chow. [17]
column3: I must be getting very feeble; 'tis long since I have had a repetition of the dreams in which I used to see the Duke of Chow. [seventeen]

column2: Concentrate the mind, said he, "upon the Good Way.
column3: Concentrate the mind, said he, "upon the Good Way.

column2: Maintain firm hold upon Virtue.	Maintain firm hold upon Virtue.
column3: true

column2: Rely upon Philanthropy.	Rely upon Philanthropy.
column3: true

column2: Find recreation in the Arts.	Find recreation in the Arts.
column3: false
[eighteen]

column2: I have never withheld instruction from any, even from those who have come for it with the smallest offering.	I have never withheld instruction from any, even from those who have come for it with the smallest offering.
column3: false

column2: No subject do I broach, however, to those who have no eager desire to learn; no encouraging hint do I give to those who show no anxiety to speak out their ideas; nor have I anything more to say to those who, after I have made clear one corner of the subject, cannot from that give me the other three.
column3: No subject do I broach, however, to those who have no eager desire to learn; no encouraging hint do I give to those who show no anxiety to speak out their ideas; nor have I anything more to say to those who, after I have made clear one corner of the subject, cannot from that give me the other three.

column2: If the Master was taking a meal, and there were any in mourning beside him, he would not eat to the full.
column3: If the Master was taking a meal, and there were any in mourning beside him, he would not eat to the full.

column2: On one day on which he had wept, on that day he would not sing.
column3: On one day on which he had wept, on that day he would not sing.

column2: Addressing his favorite disciple, he said, "To you only and myself it has been given to do this--to go when called to serve, and to go back into quiet retirement when released from office."
column3: Addressing his favorite disciple, he said, "To you only and myself it has been given to do this-to go when called to serve, and to go back into quiet retirement when released from office."

column2: Tsz-lu, hearing the remark said, "But if, sir, you had the handling of the army of one of the greater States,[19] whom would you have associated with you in that case?"
column3: t s z lu, hearing the remark said, "But if, sir, you had the handling of the army of one of the greater States,[nineteen] whom would you have associated with you in that case?"

column2: The Master answered:--
column3: The Master answered:--

column2: Not the one 'who'll rouse the tiger,' Not the one 'who'll wade the Ho;'	Not the one 'who'll rouse the tiger,' Not the one 'who'll wade the Ho;'
column3: false

column2: not the man who can die with no regret.
column3: not the man who can die with no regret.

column2: He must be one who should watch over affairs with apprehensive caution, a man fond of strategy, and of perfect skill and effectiveness in it."
column3: He must be one who should watch over affairs with apprehensive caution, a man fond of strategy, and of perfect skill and effectiveness in it."

column2: As to wealth, he remarked, "If wealth were an object that I could go in quest of, I should do so even if I had to take a whip and do grooms' work.
column3: As to wealth, he remarked, "If wealth were an object that I could go in quest of, I should do so even if I had to take a whip and do grooms' work.

column2: But seeing that it is not, I go after those objects for which I have a liking."
column3: But seeing that it is not, I go after those objects for which I have a liking."

column2: Among matters over which he exercised great caution were times of fasting, war, and sickness.
column3: Among matters over which he exercised great caution were times of fasting, war, and sickness.

column2: When he was in the State of Ts'i, and had heard the ancient Shau music, he lost all perception of the taste of his meat.
column3: When he was in the State of Ts'i, and had heard the ancient Shau music, he lost all perception of the taste of his meat.

column2: I had no idea, said he, "that music could have been brought to this pitch."
column3: I had no idea, said he, "that music could have been brought to this pitch."

column2: In the course of conversation Yen Yu said, "Does the Master take the part of the Prince of Wei?" "Ah yes!" said Tsz-kung, "I will go and ask him that."
column3: In the course of conversation Yen Yu said, "Does the Master take the part of the Prince of Wei?" "Ah yes!" said t s z kung, "I will go and ask him that."

column2: On going in to him, that disciple began, "What sort of men were Peh-I and Shuh Ts'i?" "Worthies of the olden time," the Master replied.
column3: On going in to him, that disciple began, "What sort of men were p e h I and Shuh Ts'i?" "Worthies of the olden time," the Master replied.

column2: Had they any feelings of resentment? was the next question.
column3: Had they any feelings of resentment? was the next question.

column2: Their aim and object, he answered, "was that of doing the duty which every man owes to his fellows, and they succeeded in doing it;--what room further for feelings of resentment?"
column3: Their aim and object, he answered, "was that of doing the duty which every man owes to his fellows, and they succeeded in doing it;--what room further for feelings of resentment?"

column2: The questioner on coming out said, "The Master does not take his part."
column3: The questioner on coming out said, "The Master does not take his part."

column2: With a meal of coarse rice, said the Master, "and with water to drink, and my bent arm for my pillow--even thus I can find happiness.
column3: With a meal of coarse rice, said the Master, "and with water to drink, and my bent arm for my pillow-even thus I can find happiness.

column2: Riches and honors without righteousness are to me as fleeting clouds."
column3: Riches and honors without righteousness are to me as fleeting clouds."

column2: Give me several years more to live, said he, "and after fifty years' study of the 'Book of Changes' I might come to be free from serious error."
column3: Give me several years more to live, said he, "and after fifty years' study of the 'Book of Changes' I might come to be free from serious error."

column2: The Master's regular subjects of discourse were the "Books of the Odes" and "History," and the up-keeping of the Rules of Propriety.
column3: The Master's regular subjects of discourse were the "Books of the Odes" and "History," and the up keeping of the Rules of Propriety.

column2: On all of these he regularly discoursed.
column3: On all of these he regularly discoursed.

column2: The Duke of Shih questioned Tsz-lu about Confucius, and the latter did not answer.
column3: The Duke of Shih questioned t s z lu about Confucius, and the latter did not answer.

column2: Hearing of this, the Master said, "Why did you not say, He is a man with a mind so intent on his pursuits that he forgets his food, and finds such pleasure in them that he forgets his troubles, and does not know that old age is coming upon him?"
column3: Hearing of this, the Master said, "Why did you not say, He is a man with a mind so intent on his pursuits that he forgets his food, and finds such pleasure in them that he forgets his troubles, and does not know that old age is coming upon him?"

column2: As I came not into life with any knowledge of it, he said, "and as my likings are for what is old, I busy myself in seeking knowledge there."
column3: As I came not into life with any knowledge of it, he said, "and as my likings are for what is old, I busy myself in seeking knowledge there."

column2: Strange occurrences, exploits of strength, deeds of lawlessness, references to spiritual beings--such-like matters the Master avoided in conversation.
column3: Strange occurrences, exploits of strength, deeds of lawlessness, references to spiritual beings-such like matters the Master avoided in conversation.

column2: Let there, he said, "be three men walking together: from that number I should be sure to find my instructors; for what is good in them I should choose out and follow, and what is not good I should modify."
column3: Let there, he said, "be three men walking together: from that number I should be sure to find my instructors; for what is good in them I should choose out and follow, and what is not good I should modify."

column2: On one occasion he exclaimed, "Heaven begat Virtue in me; what can man do unto me?"
column3: On one occasion he exclaimed, "Heaven begat Virtue in me; what can man do unto me?"

column2: To his disciples he once said, "Do you look upon me, my sons, as keeping anything secret from you?
column3: To his disciples he once said, "Do you look upon me, my sons, as keeping anything secret from you?

column2: I hide nothing from you.
column3: I hide nothing from you.

column2: I do nothing that is not manifest to your eyes, my disciples.
column3: I do nothing that is not manifest to your eyes, my disciples.

column2: That is so with me."
column3: That is so with me."

column2: Four things there were which he kept in view in his teaching--scholarliness, conduct of life, honesty, faithfulness.
column3: Four things there were which he kept in view in his teaching-scholarliness, conduct of life, honesty, faithfulness.

column2: It is not given to me, he said, "to meet with a sage; let me but behold a man of superior mind, and that will suffice.
column3: It is not given to me, he said, "to meet with a sage; let me but behold a man of superior mind, and that will suffice.

column2: Neither is it given to me to meet with a good man; let me but see a man of constancy, and it will suffice.
column3: Neither is it given to me to meet with a good man; let me but see a man of constancy, and it will suffice.

column2: It is difficult for persons to have constancy, when they pretend to have that which they are destitute of, to be full when they are empty, to do things on a grand scale when their means are contracted!"
column3: It is difficult for persons to have constancy, when they pretend to have that which they are destitute of, to be full when they are empty, to do things on a grand scale when their means are contracted!"

column2: When the Master fished with hook and line, he did not also use a net. When out with his bow, he would never shoot at game in cover.
column3: When the Master fished with hook and line, he did not also use a net. When out with his bow, he would never shoot at game in cover.

column2: Some there may be, said he, "who do things in ignorance of what they do.
column3: Some there may be, said he, "who do things in ignorance of what they do.

column2: I am not of these.
column3: I am not of these.

column2: There is an alternative way of knowing things, viz.--to sift out the good from the many things one hears, and follow it; and to keep in memory the many things one sees."
column3: There is an alternative way of knowing things, viz.--to sift out the good from the many things one hears, and follow it; and to keep in memory the many things one sees."

column2: Pupils from Hu-hiang were difficult to speak with.
column3: Pupils from Hu hiang were difficult to speak with.

column2: One youth came to interview the Master, and the disciples were in doubt whether he ought to have been seen.
column3: One youth came to interview the Master, and the disciples were in doubt whether he ought to have been seen.

column2: Why so much ado, said the Master, "at my merely permitting his approach, and not rather at my allowing him to draw back? If a man have cleansed himself in order to come and see me, I receive him as such; but I do not undertake for what he will do when he goes away."
column3: Why so much ado, said the Master, "at my merely permitting his approach, and not rather at my allowing him to draw back? If a man have cleansed himself in order to come and see me, I receive him as such; but I do not undertake for what he will do when he goes away."

column2: Is the philanthropic spirit far to seek, indeed? the Master exclaimed; "I wish for it, and it is with me!"
column3: Is the philanthropic spirit far to seek, indeed? the Master exclaimed; "I wish for it, and it is with me!"

column2: The Minister of Crime in the State of Ch'in asked Confucius whether Duke Ch'an, of Lu was acquainted with the Proprieties; and he answered, "Yes, he knows them."
column3: The Minister of Crime in the State of Ch'in asked Confucius whether Duke Ch'an, of Lu was acquainted with the Proprieties; and he answered, "Yes, he knows them."

column2: When Confucius had withdrawn, the minister bowed to Wu-ma K'i, a disciple, and motioned to him to come forward.
column3: When Confucius had withdrawn, the minister bowed to Wu ma K'i, a disciple, and motioned to him to come forward.

column2: He said, "I have heard that superior men show no partiality; are they, too, then, partial?
column3: He said, "I have heard that superior men show no partiality; are they, too, then, partial?

column2: That prince took for his wife a lady of the Wu family, having the same surname as himself, and had her named 'Lady Tsz of Wu, the elder,' If he knows the Proprieties, then who does not?"
column3: That prince took for his wife a lady of the Wu family, having the same surname as himself, and had her named 'Lady t s z of Wu, the elder,' If he knows the Proprieties, then who does not?"

column2: The disciple reported this to the Master, who thereupon remarked, "Well for me!
column3: The disciple reported this to the Master, who thereupon remarked, "Well for me!

column2: If I err in any way, others are sure to know of it."
column3: If I err in any way, others are sure to know of it."

column2: When the Master was in company with any one who sang, and who sang well, he must needs have the song over again, and after that would join in it.
column3: When the Master was in company with any one who sang, and who sang well, he must needs have the song over again, and after that would join in it.

column2: Although in letters, he said, "I may have none to compare with me, yet in my personification of the 'superior man' I have not as yet been successful."
column3: Although in letters, he said, "I may have none to compare with me, yet in my personification of the 'superior man' I have not as yet been successful."

column2: 'A Sage and a Philanthropist?' How should I have the ambition? said he.
column3: 'A Sage and a Philanthropist?' How should I have the ambition? said he.

column2: All that I can well be called is this--An insatiable student, an unwearied teacher;--this, and no more.--"Exactly what we, your disciples, cannot by any learning manage to be," said Kung-si Hwa.
column3: All that I can well be called is this-An insatiable student, an unwearied teacher;--this, and no more.--"Exactly what we, your disciples, cannot by any learning manage to be," said Kung si Hwa.

column2: Once when the Master was seriously ill, Tsz-lu requested to be allowed to say prayers for him.
column3: Once when the Master was seriously ill, t s z lu requested to be allowed to say prayers for him.

column2: Are such available? asked the Master.
column3: Are such available? asked the Master.

column2: Yes, said he; "and the Manual of Prayers says, 'Pray to the spirits above and to those here below,'"
column3: Yes, said he; "and the Manual of Prayers says, 'Pray to the spirits above and to those here below,'"

column2: My praying has been going on a long while, said the Master.
column3: My praying has been going on a long while, said the Master.

column2: Lavish living, he said, "renders men disorderly; miserliness makes them hard.
column3: Lavish living, he said, "renders men disorderly; miserliness makes them hard.

column2: Better, however, the hard than the disorderly."
column3: Better, however, the hard than the disorderly."

column2: Again, "The man of superior mind is placidly composed; the small-minded man is in a constant state of perturbation."
column3: Again, "The man of superior mind is placidly composed; the small minded man is in a constant state of perturbation."

column2: The Master was gentle, yet could be severe; had an over-awing presence, yet was not violent; was deferential, yet easy.
column3: The Master was gentle, yet could be severe; had an over awing presence, yet was not violent; was deferential, yet easy.
